) Certain cases present recurring, significant legal issues affecting large numbers of taxpayers. When there is a critical need for enforcement activity and Effect of with respect to such issues, cases are designated for litigation in the interest a Case for sound tax administration to establish judicial precedent, conserve resources, reduce litigation costs for the Service and taxpayers. For example, judicial precedent may provide guidance for the resolution of industry-wide, tax or other issues, thereby serving early issue resolution and conserving and taxpayer resources. (
) When under the jurisdiction of the Service, the designated issue in a case not be resolved without a full concession by the taxpayer. (
) In general, an issue will be designated when the case is under the of an Operating Division. If an issue in a case is designated, the taxpayer not receive a

-day letter with respect to remaining unresolved issues in case. Rather, the taxpayer will be issued a statutory notice of deficiency. In general, the designation of an issue in a case will not preclude the of the remaining issues after the case is docketed. Nor, in general, will nation preclude Appeals from settling the same issue in other cases within jurisdiction. As part of the designation process, Counsel will consider the issue is one of first impression or otherwise involves unique or unusual cumstances. If the Chief Counsel believes circumstances surrounding the designated issue are such that settlement of the issue in other cases would detrimental to the principles of sound tax administration, the Chief Counsel confer with the Chief, Appeals. The Chief Counsel and the Chief, Appeals, also confer as to the impact of the settlement of an issue on future and a course of action with respect to the settlement of the issue that the best interests of tax administration. The Associate Area Counsel will informally coordinate with the Associate Chief Counsel with subject matter jurisdiction of the issue proposed for designation while this memorandum. If it is intended that a different Associate Area Counsel office be responsible for the trial of the case, the preparation of the DRM will be coordinated with that trial office. If the Area Counsel concurs with the such concurrence will be reflected by a signature on the memorandum. (
) The Area Counsel will forward the DRM simultaneously to the Operating Division Executive, listed below, and the Division Counsel, who will have

days to review and concur on the proposal. Any written submissions by the taxpayer reflecting his/her views on the proposed designation will be with the DRM. Concurrence will be reflected by a signature on the memoran- dum. For purposes of advanced notice and coordination, the Area Counsel also forward a copy of the DRM to the Associate Chief Counsel with subject matter jurisdiction of the issue proposed for designation. a. In LB&I, the Operating Division Executive is the Industry Director and, if the issue to be designated is an International issue, the Deputy Commis- sioner (International). If an LB&I taxpayer in one industry is under examination by another Industry Director, concurrence is required by directors. b. In SB/SE, the Operating Division Executive is the Commissioner c. In TEGE, the Operating Division Executive is the Commissioner (TEGE). (

days of receipt of the DRM. (

) If the Chief Counsel approves designating the case for litigation, the Division Counsel will notify the executives who concurred with the DRM and the Appeals. ) This subsection sets out the procedures governing the responsibilities of Counsels prior to recommending a case for designation and the contents Designation Recommendation Memorandum. and (

) Before a case is recommended for designation, it is the responsibility of recommending Area Counsel office to: a. Articulate in a background memorandum the reasons why litigation is most desirable method of resolving the issue proposed for designation. The background memorandum shall state the goal of the proposed tion, the impact of both a favorable and an unfavorable opinion in the case, the potential impact of other issues in the case, the other of issue resolution that have been considered and why those methods not appropriate, and an analysis of the substantive issue and any issues (including penalties). b. Ensure that the issue that is proposed for designation is factually developed to its fullest, including document production, and key and third party witness interviews, when appropriate. The office should also ensure that the Service has the resources to support proposed litigation, including expert witness funds, and that the case, entirety, is appropriate for the issuance of a statutory notice of Efforts should be made to discover the existence of facts that could adversely affect the desirability of designation, such as an agreement the Service in an earlier year with the taxpayer contrary to the position now proposed. c. Thoroughly research the issue to ensure that the litigating position of Service is established, clear, and well-founded on statute and Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

33.3.6.3 (08-11-2004) Background Development and DesignationRecommendationMemorandum

recommending Area Counsel office to: a. Articulate in a background memorandum the reasons why litigation is the most desirable method of resolving the issue proposed for designation. The background memorandum shall state the goal of the proposed litiga

tion, the impact of both a favorable and an unfavorable opinion in the case, the potential impact of other issues in the case, the other methods of issue resolution that have been considered and why those methods are not appropriate, and an analysis of the substantive issue and any related issues (including penalties). b. Ensure that the issue that is proposed for designation is factually developed to its fullest, including document production, and key taxpayer and third party witness interviews, when appropriate. The recommending office should also ensure that the Service has the resources to support the proposed litigation, including expert witness funds, and that the case, in its entirety, is appropriate for the issuance of a statutory notice of deficiency. Efforts should be made to discover the existence of facts that could adversely affect the desirability of designation, such as an agreement with the Service in an earlier year with the taxpayer contrary to the position now proposed. c. Thoroughly research the issue to ensure that the litigating position of the Service is established, clear, and well
founded on statute and published
Thoroughly research the issue to ensure that the litigating position of the Service is established, clear, and well-founded on statute and published
a Case for Litigation 33.3.6

positions. The recommending office shall ascertain the litigating position the Service through coordination with its Area Counsel, Division and the Associate Chief Counsel office with subject matter jurisdiction the issue. Coordination with other Counsel offices may occur, as ate.
The Designation Recommendation Memorandum (DRM) will contain the infor- mation listed below and generally be in the form of Exhibit

: a. The issue to be designated, including the amount of the adjustment, ap- proximate resulting deficiency and penalties, if applicable, with respect to the designated issue. b. The tax years, total adjustments, total deficiencies, and total penalties involved in the case, as well as the number and identity of the other solved issues in the case. c. A brief examination history of the taxpayer. This discussion should the prior treatment or resolution of the issue proposed for designation, rulings or adjustments previously made that are related to the litigation issue, and the possibility of carryforwards or carrybacks that would moot the trial of the case. This discussion should also state whether the of limitations is a potential problem and whether the taxpayer is in a position to withdraw a consent or refuse to execute a new one. d. The purpose of the proposed designation. This discussion should explain why litigation is the preferred strategy for resolving the issued involved. Rejection, or coordinated use, of non-litigation strategies, such as regula- tions, rulings, or legislation, must also be explained. e. A factual summary of the designated issue and any related issues (including penalties). This discussion should highlight significant and unfavorable facts, state whether there are any areas of factual dis- agreement, explain the significance of the disagreement, and set forth lack of availability of material evidence or witnesses. If expert testimony required, this discussion should include the nature of the expert whether experts are available, and an approximation of costs to be incurred in procuring experts. Significant evidentiary issues should be discussed. f. A legal analysis reflecting the litigating position of the Service. This sion should contain an analysis of the law and how the law applies to the particular facts. Key advice memoranda should be attached. g. A discussion of the litigating position of the taxpayer. This discussion should include comments regarding the law or facts advanced by the taxpayer in support of its position, and in opposition to the Serviceâ€™s position, the time needed to prepare the case for trial and the estimated trial time. If the taxpayer made a written submission in response to the notification that designation was under consideration, a copy of that response should be attached. h. A discussion of the anticipated taxpayer strategy. This discussion should include whether the taxpayer may choose to litigate in a refund setting, likely appellate forum, and whether the taxpayer may invoke Competent Authority procedures. These possibilities should be considered as factors mitigating against designation and the discussion should explain why ignation is nonetheless appropriate. i. A recommendation on which Associate Area Counsel would have overall supervision of the trial of the case and the lead trial counsel.
The Designation Recommendation Memorandum (DRM) will contain the infor- mation listed below and generally be in the form of Exhibit 33.3.6-1:
A recommendation on which Associate Area Counsel would have overall supervision of the trial of the case and the lead trial counsel.

) Designation of a case for litigation should not be made in contemplation of later release of the designation. The litigating position of the Service may change or new facts may come to light so that continuation of litigation no longer serves the purpose for which the designation was originally made. Under such circumstances, release of the designation may be considered. (
) Recommendations for release of designation may originate from the Division, the Area Counsel, Division Counsel, Chief, Appeals, Associate Counsel, or the Chief Counsel. (
) The decision to release or not release a designation will be made by the Counsel or the Chief Counselâ€™s delegate. (
) If release of designation is approved, the taxpayer will be informed in by the Area Counsel responsible for the case. (

) If a case that has been designated for litigation proceeds to trial in a refund litigation status procedure, the case will be classified as â€œStandardâ€ under Cases refund litigation procedures. See CCDM

, Case Classification. Area Counsel office responsible for the preparation of the refund defense will work with the Division Counsel and the Associate Chief Counsel with subject matter jurisdiction to articulate in the defense letter the goals of the designation. The Office of Chief Counsel will give full support to the Depart- ment of Justiceâ€™s litigation of a designated case, which may include Counsel resources to trial preparation activities and trial.

Designation of a case for litigation should not be made in contemplation of a later release of the designation. The litigating position of the Service may change or new facts may come to light so that continuation of litigation no longer serves the purpose for which the designation was originally made. Under such circumstances, release of the designation may be considered.

Associate Area Counsel, Large Business and International (LB&I)
Pursuant to the provisions of CCDM 33.3.6, we recommend that an issue arising out of the examination of [Taxpayer] be designated for litigation.
